channel.title: Omg!
channel.description:
well i finally found out how to find the string class and started playing around with it and i got it to print this :D (after running the client)
Starting game engine... Prepared visibility map Connecting to update server... Checking for updates... Loaded update list Prepared sound engine Loading fonts - 0% Loaded fonts
while runescape was loading :D :D :D :D

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

ruler:

One day i wish people would stop assuming dectability issues and actually statistically figure them out.

Do you know what you speak of? Statistics are one thing, facts are another; ie. Statistically, a Rice study showed a 33% quicker, and up to a 55% better quality surgery of that of a doctor who played video games at least 30 minutes a day as apposed to the control group which played none. Statistically it is better, but factually, video games effect peoples’ minds differently, in some doctors there was a significant decrease in efficiency… Therefore it’s better to look at facts and not statistics.

The facts of the client are: There is a reflection system, there is an incrementor check summary, there is a “random” check, there is a mouse* monitoring algorithm that catches most automated mouse events, there is a focus watcher to make sure input is sent when the client has focus and not when its minimized, there is a graphics bound system that verifies focus events through clips that Sun and some other Java’s automaticly generate… These are the facts.

The statistics of the client are: Most of the above will not get you automatically banned, with the exceptions of the invalid inputs, the invalid incrementor checksums, and the reflection system. The statistic shows that you most likely will not get banned, but does not oppose the fact that the traps exist.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @r4ndom1 r4ndom1
item.description:
@r4ndom1 wrote:

Silver Lining:

And of course, it’s so difficult to get around the method counting. One line of simple reflection.

of course if you remove the method counting and start forcing actions without moving the mouse it isnt going to trip any server side traps.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Bypassing the method counters really isn’t all that easy. Don’t forget, often a call to one method results in thousands of ‘descendant’ method calls, which may be unpredictable (to a certain degree). It’s obviously far from impossible, but it wouldn’t be too fun either.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

sh!ft: My bad.

A bot should not call client methods under ANY circumstances. If they cant check if a tile is reachable by itself then it is not a well coded bot. That said it would be easy to bypass the method counters with either reflection or all out bytecode hacking.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

The %1 %2 etc… is just the placement of which variable to place in the string at that point. The
is standard html. So after thinking about it, its probably something they made up themselves to have a mixture of stuff to input into a method to parse and format it correctly.

its obvious they are not trying to hide anything by what they are doing here.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Nerice, post:42, topic:148740”][quote author=remove_later link=topic=203955.msg1807228#msg1807228 date=1191742662]

How do you mean the strings a fractured. If I look in most strings I always see normal strings. You do see %1 etc and other strange combination but those have special meaning in the way it looks. (%1 etc are variables)

I did once print all the static strings available, and you get them perfect.
[/quote]%1 etc arent variables, just just how characters are encoded to store inside a byte array

Why do they have text like this then?
Attack XP: %1
Next level at: %2
Run (on) Energy %1%
Combat Lvl: %1

Maybe they invoke a method to use those and the '%1’s are simply things that are sesrched for and replaced with a variable which is one of the method’s argument’s value.
For example:

MyClass.MyMethod("Hello the number one is %1", 1);

sort of?

yeah either thier own homegrown version of printf/sprintf or modified sun’s version to do the work for them.[/quote]i will deob a client sometime soon, this has got me interested, i assume they just pass an array of strings for the args?

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

Mopman:

Silly question, but why do the deobs have to be renamed before use?

Java has no problem running away with severely mangled names, Javac however, does. Thus we either have to rename or use a different compiler.

“Throw handlers”, bash? I hope to god you mean exception handling.

Deobs are fine, however runescape’s reflection system will try to get the access rights of a field, or the value of a field with the member profile “cx.A{I}” or int cx.A… The only issue is, we’ve renamed cx.A to say Class32.anInt554… So when reflection looks for said field it gets nothing and returns null values across the board throwing all sorts of flags server side.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

They can not be recompiled for two reasons: 1) The compiler doesn’t know if you mean a method, field or class. 2) There tends to be throw handlers that trip compilers up as well as other obfuscation that makes the code unreadable or cause stack overflows in jode.

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

deobs dont, but they usually are if they are to be decompiled so that they can be recompiled, only for testing stuff though, you would never run a renamed client without a system to map the names back

Read full topic

item.title: Omg!
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“sh!ft, post:31, topic:148740”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=203955.msg1804514#msg1804514 date=1191663082]
Tbh, can they detect interfaces? Or extra fields? If so, I’m kind of fucked for a while then.
[/quote]
They can, but even then the work around that routine is maybe fifty lines of code? The detection routine is just meant to scare off the lazy programmer, and apparently, often does. Specifically, they do not detect interfaces, as far as I know, however they can detect methods and fields.[/quote]So, basically I just have to remove the contents of this routine, and win?[br][size=1]Posted on: October 06, 2007, 04:33:08 AM[/size][hr][quote=“qauters, post:32, topic:148740”]There is no point in creating an interface, if they can detect methods. They don’t detect it, otherwise I would be banned long time ago.[/quote]Do you understand that they can tell the difference between method names, hence why renaming isn’t to good of a thing?

Read full topic

Pwnd:

Tbh, can they detect interfaces? Or extra fields? If so, I’m kind of fucked for a while then.

They can, but even then the work around that routine is maybe fifty lines of code? The detection routine is just meant to scare off the lazy programmer, and apparently, often does. Specifically, they do not detect interfaces, as far as I know, however they can detect methods and fields.
